issues.description: The Meal constructor parameter order in the template does not match the problem specification (UML) and the example usage in Main. The UML and example use Meal(String name, String[] ingredients), and the solution implements that signature. However, the template's Meal constructor is declared as Meal(String[] ingredients, String name). This will cause compile errors for students who follow the problem statement or the Main example and will block implementing or testing code that expects the name-first constructor.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the Meal constructor in the template to match the specification and example usage: declare it as public Meal(String name, String[] ingredients) and assign fields accordingly. This will align the template with the UML, the Main example, and the solution.

issues.description: The problem statement (and the solution) describe the Meal constructor as Meal(String name, String[] ingredients) (name first, then ingredients). The template implementation has the parameter order reversed: public Meal(String[] ingredients, String name). The template's Main also shows calls using the (name, ingredients) order, which will not match the template Meal constructor. This mismatch between the problem description/solution and the template will cause compile errors and confusion: students reading the problem and example Main will expect a constructor taking (String, String[]) but the provided template signature is (String[], String).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template Meal constructor match the problem statement and solution: change the constructor signature in template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Meal.java to public Meal(String name, String[] ingredients) and assign fields accordingly (this.name = name; this.ingredients = ingredients). This aligns the template, sample Main usage, problem description, and solution, avoiding compile-time confusion.
